claim: Bangkok gets more international arrivals than Paris.

supporting.text: Bangkok is one of the most visited cities in the world, with over 20 million international arrivals annually, surpassing Paris.

attacks.text: Bangkok is one of the most visited cities in the world, with over 20 million international arrivals annually, surpassing Paris.
Paris has consistently ranked higher in international arrivals, with official reports showing over 38 million visitors in recent years, far exceeding Bangkok's numbers.
The 20 million figure for Bangkok includes domestic travelers, whereas the Paris statistics strictly count international arrivals, making the comparison misleading.
Bangkok's tourism authority explicitly separates domestic and international arrivals in their reports, confirming the 20 million figure refers solely to international visitors.
Bangkok's high arrival numbers are heavily skewed by short-term layover travelers who don't actually visit the city, unlike Paris where most arrivals are destination tourists.
Airport transit data shows less than 15% of Bangkok's international arrivals are layovers, with the vast majority entering Thailand through immigration.

supporting.text: Paris, while a major tourist destination, receives fewer international arrivals than Bangkok due to Bangkok's role as a global hub for tourism and business in Southeast Asia.

attacks.text: Paris, while a major tourist destination, receives fewer international arrivals than Bangkok due to Bangkok's role as a global hub for tourism and business in Southeast Asia.
Paris remains the most visited city in the world, with higher international tourist arrivals than Bangkok, as per recent global tourism reports.
The data comparing Paris and Bangkok's arrivals may vary by source, but Bangkok's strategic location and lower costs attract more regional travelers, skewing the numbers.
Bangkok's arrivals include many transit passengers who do not stay long, whereas Paris attracts dedicated tourists, making direct comparisons misleading.
Even accounting for transit passengers, Bangkok's tourism infrastructure and visa policies significantly boost its international arrival numbers over Paris.

supporting.text: Data from international tourism organizations consistently rank Bangkok higher than Paris in terms of annual international arrivals.

attacks.text: Data from international tourism organizations consistently rank Bangkok higher than Paris in terms of annual international arrivals.
The data may not account for layover passengers who transit through Bangkok but do not actually visit the city, inflating the arrival numbers.
Tourism organizations typically adjust their data to exclude transit passengers, focusing only on those who enter the country for tourism or business.
Paris attracts more long-stay tourists who contribute significantly to the economy, whereas Bangkok's higher numbers may include many short-term visitors.
International arrival statistics measure visitor volume, not economic impact, so the claim about Bangkok's higher arrivals remains valid regardless of stay duration.

supporting.text: Bangkok's strategic location and lower travel costs attract more international visitors compared to Paris, which has higher travel and accommodation expenses.

attacks.text: Bangkok's strategic location and lower travel costs attract more international visitors compared to Paris, which has higher travel and accommodation expenses.
Paris remains a top cultural and historical destination, attracting high-spending tourists who offset lower visitor numbers with longer stays and higher expenditure.
Bangkok's affordability and connectivity make it more accessible to budget travelers from nearby regions, increasing its total visitor count significantly.
Official tourism statistics from France show Paris consistently ranks higher in international arrivals when adjusted for transit and short-stay visitors.
Many travelers use Bangkok as a regional hub, inflating arrival numbers without corresponding tourism revenue or extended stays.

supporting.text: Paris, despite its cultural and historical significance, does not match Bangkok's volume of international arrivals, as Bangkok serves as a gateway for broader regional tourism.

attacks.text: Paris, despite its cultural and historical significance, does not match Bangkok's volume of international arrivals, as Bangkok serves as a gateway for broader regional tourism.
Paris remains the most visited city in the world by international tourists, with official statistics consistently ranking it higher than Bangkok.
The ranking of Paris as the most visited city often includes domestic tourists, whereas Bangkok's figures are more heavily weighted toward international arrivals.
Bangkok's tourism numbers are inflated by transit passengers who do not actually stay in the city, unlike Paris where most visitors are destination tourists.
Even accounting for transit passengers, Bangkok's international arrivals still exceed Paris's when measured by immigration data and hotel stays.
